confusables.rule: Masculine nouns use 'le', feminine nouns use 'la'
confusables.correct: le livre (the book - masculine)
confusables.explanation: Nouns have grammatical gender in French. 'Livre' is masculine, so it requires 'le'.

confusables.rule: Masculine nouns use 'un', feminine nouns use 'une'
confusables.correct: une maison (a house - feminine)
confusables.explanation: The indefinite article must match the noun's gender. 'Maison' is feminine.

confusables.rule: 'Son' for masculine nouns, 'sa' for feminine nouns (possession)
confusables.correct: sa mère (his/her mother - feminine)
confusables.explanation: Possessive adjectives agree with the noun possessed, not the possessor.

confusables.rule: Use 'son' before feminine nouns starting with vowels
confusables.correct: son amie (his/her friend - feminine but starts with 'a')
confusables.explanation: For euphony, 'son' is used before feminine nouns beginning with vowels or mute h.

confusables.rule: 'Ce' for masculine, 'cette' for feminine (demonstrative)
confusables.correct: cette femme (this woman - feminine)
confusables.explanation: Demonstrative adjectives must agree in gender with the noun.

confusables.rule: Use 'cet' before masculine nouns starting with vowels
confusables.correct: cet homme (this man - masculine but starts with 'h')
confusables.explanation: For euphony, 'cet' is used before masculine singular nouns beginning with vowels or mute h.

confusables.rule: 'Au' (à + le) for masculine, 'à la' for feminine
confusables.correct: au restaurant (to the restaurant - masculine)
confusables.explanation: The preposition 'à' contracts with 'le' to form 'au' but not with 'la'.

confusables.rule: 'Du' (de + le) for masculine, 'de la' for feminine
confusables.correct: du pain (some bread - masculine)
confusables.explanation: The partitive article uses 'du' for masculine nouns and 'de la' for feminine.

confusables.rule: Always use 'aux', never 'à les'
confusables.correct: aux enfants (to the children)
confusables.explanation: The preposition 'à' always contracts with 'les' to form 'aux'.

confusables.rule: Always use 'des', never 'de les'
confusables.correct: des livres (some books)
confusables.explanation: The preposition 'de' always contracts with 'les' to form 'des'.

confusables.rule: Use 'savoir' for facts, skills, how to do something
confusables.correct: Je sais parler français (I know how to speak French)
confusables.explanation: 'Savoir' is used for knowledge of facts or how to do something (+ infinitive).

confusables.rule: Use 'connaître' for people, places, things (familiarity)
confusables.correct: Je connais Marie (I know Marie)
confusables.explanation: 'Connaître' expresses familiarity with people, places, or things.

confusables.rule: Most verbs use 'avoir' in passé composé, but movement/reflexive verbs use 'être'
confusables.correct: Je suis allé (I went - verb of movement)
confusables.explanation: Verbs of movement (aller, venir, arriver, partir, etc.) use 'être' as auxiliary.

confusables.rule: Reflexive verbs always use 'être' in passé composé
confusables.correct: Je me suis levé (I got up - reflexive)
confusables.explanation: All reflexive/pronominal verbs use 'être' as their auxiliary in compound tenses.

confusables.rule: Use 'pendant' for completed duration, 'pour' for intended/future duration
confusables.correct: J'ai travaillé pendant trois heures (I worked for three hours - completed)
confusables.explanation: 'Pendant' describes actual duration of a completed action.

confusables.rule: Use 'pour' for intended/future duration
confusables.correct: Je vais à Paris pour trois jours (I'm going to Paris for three days - intended)
confusables.incorrect: Je vais à Paris pendant trois jours
confusables.explanation: 'Pour' indicates an intended or planned duration, especially with future actions.

confusables.rule: Use 'à' for 'to/in' a city, 'de' for 'from' a city
confusables.correct: Je vais à Paris (I'm going to Paris)
confusables.explanation: 'À' indicates destination or location with cities.

confusables.rule: Use 'en' for feminine countries, 'au' for masculine countries
confusables.correct: Je vais en France (I'm going to France - feminine)
confusables.explanation: Feminine countries (usually ending in -e) use 'en' without an article.

confusables.rule: Use 'au' for masculine countries, 'en' for feminine countries
confusables.correct: Je vais au Canada (I'm going to Canada - masculine)
confusables.explanation: Masculine countries use 'au' (à + le) to indicate destination.

confusables.rule: Use 'de' for origin/from, 'depuis' for since/for (time)
confusables.correct: Je viens de Paris (I come from Paris)
confusables.explanation: 'De' indicates origin or source.

confusables.rule: Use 'depuis' with present tense for ongoing action, 'il y a' with passé composé for completed action
confusables.correct: J'habite ici depuis trois ans (I've been living here for three years - ongoing)
confusables.incorrect: J'habite ici il y a trois ans
confusables.explanation: 'Depuis' + present tense describes an action that started in the past and continues.

confusables.rule: Use 'il y a' for ago (completed action)
confusables.correct: Je suis arrivé il y a trois ans (I arrived three years ago - completed)
confusables.incorrect: Je suis arrivé depuis trois ans
confusables.explanation: 'Il y a' indicates a point in the past when a completed action occurred.

confusables.rule: Use 'y' to replace 'à/dans/sur + place', 'en' to replace 'de + place'
confusables.correct: Je vais à Paris. J'y vais. (I'm going to Paris. I'm going there.)
confusables.explanation: 'Y' replaces prepositional phrases with à, dans, sur, chez + location.

confusables.rule: Use 'en' to replace 'de + thing' or quantities
confusables.correct: J'ai du pain. J'en ai. (I have some bread. I have some.)
confusables.explanation: 'En' replaces de + noun, partitive articles, or quantities.

confusables.rule: 'Lui' for singular indirect object, 'leur' for plural
confusables.correct: Je leur parle (I speak to them)
confusables.incorrect: Je lui parle (when referring to multiple people)
confusables.explanation: Indirect object pronouns: lui (to him/her), leur (to them).

confusables.rule: Use 'le/la/les' for direct objects, 'lui/leur' for indirect objects
confusables.correct: Je lui donne le livre (I give the book to him - indirect object)
confusables.explanation: Direct objects receive the action directly; indirect objects receive it indirectly (to/for someone).

confusables.rule: Direct object pronouns agree in gender/number with the noun they replace
confusables.correct: La pomme? Je la mange. (The apple? I'm eating it.)
confusables.explanation: Direct object pronouns must match the gender and number of the replaced noun.

confusables.rule: Use 'bon' (adjective) to describe nouns
confusables.correct: C'est un bon livre (It's a good book)
confusables.explanation: 'Bon' is an adjective that modifies nouns.

confusables.rule: Use 'bien' (adverb) to describe verbs or as predicate
confusables.correct: Il parle bien (He speaks well)
confusables.explanation: 'Bien' is an adverb that modifies verbs or describes states.

confusables.rule: Use 'mauvais' (adjective) to describe nouns
confusables.correct: C'est un mauvais film (It's a bad movie)
confusables.explanation: 'Mauvais' is an adjective that modifies nouns.

confusables.rule: Use 'mal' (adverb) to describe verbs
confusables.correct: Il chante mal (He sings badly)
confusables.explanation: 'Mal' is an adverb that modifies verbs.

confusables.rule: 'Tout' for singular, 'tous' for plural masculine
confusables.correct: tous les jours (every day - plural)
confusables.explanation: 'Tout/tous/toute/toutes' must agree with the noun in gender and number.

confusables.rule: Use 'c'est' + noun/adjective for identification, 'il est' + adjective for description
confusables.correct: C'est un professeur (He is a teacher - identification with noun)
confusables.explanation: 'C'est' is used with nouns, modified nouns, proper names, or stressed pronouns.

confusables.rule: Use 'il est' + profession (no article) for description
confusables.correct: Il est professeur (He is a teacher - profession as description)
confusables.explanation: When stating profession, nationality, or religion as a characteristic, use 'il/elle est' without article.

confusables.rule: Use 'qui' as subject of relative clause, 'que' as object
confusables.correct: L'homme qui parle (The man who speaks - subject)
confusables.explanation: 'Qui' is the subject pronoun in a relative clause (followed by verb).

confusables.rule: Use 'que' as object of relative clause
confusables.correct: Le livre que je lis (The book that I'm reading - object)
confusables.explanation: 'Que' is the object pronoun in a relative clause (followed by subject + verb).

confusables.rule: 'A' is 'avoir' conjugated (has), 'à' is preposition (to/at)
confusables.correct: Il a un livre (He has a book)
confusables.explanation: 'A' (no accent) is the third person singular of 'avoir'.

confusables.rule: 'À' is preposition (to/at), 'a' is conjugated 'avoir'
confusables.correct: Je vais à Paris (I'm going to Paris)
confusables.explanation: 'À' (with accent) is a preposition meaning 'to' or 'at'.

confusables.rule: 'Est' is 'être' conjugated (is), 'et' is conjunction (and)
confusables.correct: Il est grand et beau (He is tall and handsome)
confusables.explanation: 'Est' is the third person singular of 'être'; 'et' means 'and'.

confusables.rule: 'Sont' is 'être' plural (are), 'son' is possessive (his/her)
confusables.correct: Ils sont ici (They are here)
confusables.explanation: 'Sont' is the third person plural of 'être'.

confusables.rule: 'Ont' is 'avoir' plural (have), 'on' is pronoun (one/we)
confusables.correct: Ils ont des livres (They have books)
confusables.explanation: 'Ont' is the third person plural of 'avoir'.

confusables.rule: 'Ces' is demonstrative (these/those), 'ses' is possessive (his/her - plural)
confusables.correct: ses livres (his/her books - possession)
confusables.explanation: 'Ses' shows possession (his/her), 'ces' points out (these/those).

confusables.rule: 'Ce' is demonstrative (this/that), 'se' is reflexive pronoun
confusables.correct: Il se lave (He washes himself - reflexive)
confusables.explanation: 'Se' is a reflexive pronoun used with pronominal verbs.

confusables.rule: 'Leur' for singular possession, 'leurs' for plural
confusables.correct: leur maison (their house - singular object)
confusables.explanation: Possessive adjectives agree with the thing possessed, not the possessor.

confusables.rule: 'Où' means 'where', 'ou' means 'or'
confusables.correct: Où vas-tu? (Where are you going?)
confusables.explanation: 'Où' (with accent) is used for questions or relative clauses about location.

confusables.rule: 'La' is article/pronoun (the/her/it), 'là' is adverb (there)
confusables.correct: Je suis là (I'm there/here)
confusables.explanation: 'Là' (with accent) means 'there' or 'here' (location).

confusables.rule: 'Peux' for je/tu, 'peut' for il/elle/on
confusables.correct: Je peux venir (I can come)
confusables.explanation: 'Pouvoir' conjugates: je peux, tu peux, il/elle/on peut.

confusables.rule: 'Veux' for je/tu, 'veut' for il/elle/on
confusables.correct: Tu veux partir? (Do you want to leave?)
confusables.explanation: 'Vouloir' conjugates: je veux, tu veux, il/elle/on veut.

confusables.rule: 'Sais' for je/tu, 'sait' for il/elle/on
confusables.correct: Tu sais nager? (Do you know how to swim?)
confusables.explanation: 'Savoir' conjugates: je sais, tu sais, il/elle/on sait.

confusables.rule: 'Fais' for je/tu, 'fait' for il/elle/on
confusables.correct: Que fais-tu? (What are you doing?)
confusables.explanation: 'Faire' conjugates: je fais, tu fais, il/elle/on fait.

confusables.rule: 'Vas' for tu (with hyphen in questions), 'va' for il/elle/on
confusables.correct: Où vas-tu? (Where are you going?)
confusables.explanation: 'Aller' conjugates: je vais, tu vas, il/elle/on va. 'Vas' is used with inversion.

confusables.rule: Use imparfait for ongoing/habitual past actions, passé composé for completed actions
confusables.correct: Je lisais quand tu es arrivé (I was reading when you arrived)
confusables.incorrect: J'ai lu quand tu es arrivé
confusables.explanation: Imparfait describes background/ongoing actions; passé composé describes specific completed events.

confusables.rule: Use subjunctive after expressions of doubt, emotion, necessity, possibility
confusables.correct: Il faut que je parte (It's necessary that I leave - subjunctive)
confusables.explanation: After 'il faut que', 'bien que', 'pour que', etc., use the subjunctive mood.

confusables.rule: 'Ne' comes before verb, 'pas' after verb (or auxiliary)
confusables.correct: Je ne sais pas (I don't know)
confusables.explanation: Negation wraps around the conjugated verb: ne + verb + pas.

confusables.rule: 'Ne...jamais' = never, 'ne...rien' = nothing (don't confuse)
confusables.correct: Je ne vois rien (I see nothing)
confusables.explanation: Different negative expressions have different meanings: jamais (never), rien (nothing), personne (no one), plus (no more).

confusables.rule: 'Quelque chose' = something (thing), 'quelqu'un' = someone (person)
confusables.correct: J'ai vu quelqu'un (I saw someone - person)
confusables.incorrect: J'ai vu quelque chose (when referring to a person)
confusables.explanation: Use 'quelqu'un' for people, 'quelque chose' for things.

metadata.description: Comprehensive database of commonly confused French word pairs for error detection in the Allons-y! extension
metadata.usage: Each confusable entry includes the confused words, grammatical rule, correct/incorrect examples, FSI unit coverage, and detailed explanation
